indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Increased public debate, interest and policy dialogue on the role of civil society in Egypt. HDI calculated and disseminated. Enhanced MDG reporting and awareness.

baseline.comment:
No comprehensive report on status of Civil Society In Egypt.
Latest HDI was calculated and disseminated in 2005
Last MDG Report was published in 2004

target.comment: • Team of authors for the 2014/2015 EHDR recruited. • Quantitative and qualitative research required for EHDR commissioned • Draft report finalized

actual.comment: • The team of authors was formulated and 3 authors were contracted. • Dr. Amr Adly submitted background paper for the first chapter on the political economy of social justice in Egypt. Also, INP is working on data required for the NHDR. • The draft of report was not finalized.

target.comment: • Finalize Quantitative and qualitative research required for NHDR. • Finalize draft report. • To commission Translators and editors.

actual.comment: • More than 15 multi-disciplinary authors have produced background papers and statistical indicators for social justice. • The report introduced a composite index on Social Justice looking at 5 gaps: poverty and wealth, gender, regional disparities, inter-generational gaps and disability. • UNDP facilitated the production of the 2015 MDG Report which offers a good resource of baseline data for the pre-SDGs campaigns and new SDG indicators. • The draft of NHDR report was finalized and shared with readers. • 7 Policy briefs are being drafted. • Translators and editors are contracted.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Percentage of programmes outlined in the 2005 Egypt HDR adopted

baseline.comment: Approximately 50% of the 55 social programmes outlined in the 2005 Egypt HDR have been adopted by the Government. No social policy index available. No coordinated efforts to oversee Egypt’s progress towards the achievement of the new social contract

target.comment: - The capacity of Youth, Media, NGOs , Civil Society Groups, professional syndicates, trade unions and social initiatives developed and such groups engaged in dialogue on socio-economic rights, good governance and anti-corruption through training workshops, consultations, and seminars - Youth Outreach Programme institutionalized in all national universities - Skills of SCC staff enhanced and their capacities improved in new techniques and methodologies related to good governance, social accountability and socio-economic rights, fighting corruption, poverty measurement

actual.comment: • The SCC organized workshops targeting different civil society groups where 64 CS organizations were engaged with around 3053 participants in 7 governorates (Cairo, Minia , Qena, Sohag, Tanta, Asswan and Assuit) as follows:  A civic engagement training program in partnership with the Ministry of Youth. 39% of the participants were females.  8 youth economic empowerment workshops. Five workshops addressed Personal skills and 2 workshops were on employment skills. 63% of the participants were females.  A workshop with civil society organizations working in the field of anti-corruption to discuss a draft matrix developed by SCC was organized.  A capacity building workshop in the poorest villages in Minia was empowering youth to conduct community needs assessment  A workshop with civil society organizations working in the education sector to identify development gaps and design an integrated plan in Assuit  88 workshops conducted by trained participants (ToT).  A total of 22 youth capacity building workshops ( with total of 88 training courses ) in cooperation with 4 governmental universities (Tanta, South Valley, Assiut & Aswan)  3 workshops with media specialists to raise their awareness and interest about their roles in fighting corruption while providing them with necessary skills and knowledge.  2 workshops about governance and anti-corruption in the health and education sectors. • 3 Social Contract Clubs were formed in the Upper Egyptian Universities of Aswan, Assiut and South Valley.Some universities replicated the youth capacity building program, in coordination with student unions and the university administration. The SCC was approached by the Supreme Council of Universities to sign an agreement for 2015 program implementation. • 4 national events/workshops/conferences attended by SCC staff to improve their capacities and 2 international ones where 15 staff members participated.

iati-activity.description: The Social Contract Center aims to provide first class policy advice and coordinate with various stakeholders to develop and articulate a vision for a new social contract rooted in principles of democratic governance and modern concepts of citizenship.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To facilitate and accelerate the market development of new bioenergy technologies (BET) in Egypt, thereby promoting the sustainable socio-economic development of rural communities in Egypt and reducing the negative global and local environmental impacts associated with the use of fossil fuels and the environmentally unsound management of agricultural and solid waste. To remove the technical, institutional, information, financial, and market barriers to developing the bioenergy technology market in Egypt

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: High level of confidence

actual.comment:
457 household biogas units in 18 Governorates have now been installed either by the legally registered BSPs of trained engineers and masons or through the batches of training for 20 groups of an engineer and a mason. Total number of installed units till June 30, 2015 is 917 household biogas units.
More than 85% of the units are functioning well and producing biogas with great satisfaction communicated by the beneficiaries (households) through the monitoring sheets completed by the beneficiaries during the periodic monitoring visits of the BSPs and the project monitoring staff during random visits and phonecalls to benifichiaries..
20 groups, each consisting of one engineer and one mason, have participated in 50-day on-job training on building, curing, connecting and maintaining the household biogas units. The training took place in 5 governorates, namely; Fayoum, Assuit, Sharkeya, Beni Sweif and Menya. This btraining batch was not the project’s own trained engineers and masons but were trained by graduates of the first and second batches under the supervision of the project’s engineers and masons. Only 16 groups, each consisting of one engineer and one mason, finished their training as well as registering their documents and already entered the market after testing them theoretically and Practically.
The project succeeded in installing the biggest commercial biogas unit (50M3/day) in Fayoum in one of the big cattle farm. It is a German design and similar to the Indian design applied in the household units. It is installed by project masons under the supervision of project’s engineers. The installed commercial unit is now producing gas and bio fertilizer and project is in the process of generating electricity.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: Average annual 20% market growth at the end of the project, as compared to the previous year.

actual.comment:
Egypt is now moving towards adopting the feed-in-tariff for the biogas that is a very important step in the development of the country’s significant potential for renewable energy generation, while pursuing equally important economic, environmental and social policy objectives.
Egypt is continuing the gradually reducing fuel subsidies. This is already the case for diesel, gasoline and natural gas, and will soon also be applied to LPG cylinders. What added to the importance pf the biogas household units is that the paid cost of the units, especially with the cost share of the project, means that the payback time of the unit is just 24 months.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: Supportive policy, including required financial and fiscal incentives, in place to sustain market growth.

actual.comment:
The 295 family-size biogas units installed under the first and second waves of project installations have now been functioning well for more than thirty months and beneficiaries are satisfied. Additional biogas units are currently installed, either during the on-the-job training or by the legally registered BSPs.
As for the community units, the project has succeeded in installing Fifty Five larger units that each serves three households. The units have been functioning well for almost eighteen months.
One commercial size unit in a cattle farm is now working for more than three months and still working on electricity generation.
The project elaborated on the formal correspondence with governors of the potential governorates and organized orientation and introductory meeting for the Heads of Centers and Villages to talk to them about the project, its activities, importance of the biogas units and how to reach the companies. Dring the meetings, the project provided number of informative posters and brochures to put on governmental buildings to attract the biggest number of local citizens going there. This action increase number of beneficiaries and opened the market for the newly registered BSPs.
Five batches of 16 engineers and 16 masons were trained and now training is provided individually for each group in sight; in their home villages through project staff.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: New business and financing models successfully introduced using appropriate technical solutions and demonstrating the possibility to construct and operate BET systems on a cost recovery basis under a supportive and enabling policy and financing environment.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: At least 1,000 family-scale, 10 community-scale and 2 farm-scale biogas systems constructed and commissioned by the end of the project.

actual.comment: e hired financial and management consultant worked with the registered BSPs, and provided draft financial data set with the purpose of assessing the financial feasibility and institutional set-up of a self-sustaining 'vehicle'. It is presented and approved by Project Steering Committee and started the process of registering this “Vehicle” as a Centralized Association under the name of “Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association”. The founder is a legal person representing Ministry of Environment, and the members of the Board of Trustees are also legal persons, representing the ministries and agencies that are members of project’s steering committee.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: For gasification and/or combustion plants, at least 4 MW of installed new capacity reached by the end of the project.

actual.comment:
To maintain beneficiaries’ satisfaction, BSPs have also been trained on the monitoring process. Their fees are contingent not only on successful construction of the units but also one year of monitoring of the units. BSPs are responsible to provide the project with a satisfactory certificate filled and signed by the beneficiary every three months to get the last four installments of unit’s price. Each installment is against a certificate and this covers a period of one year after gas production from any biogas unit.
Project’s monitoring staff are visiting random samples of functioning units and calling customers via phone periodically to assure their satisfaction and double check BSPs work. Monitoring is not only for the units installed by the but also for the units installed by the project as well as the trainees.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: Over 90% of the customers satisfied with the new units

actual.comment:
The project continued to urge governmental and non-governmental entities to support the idea and convince people to visit the installed units. The project also organized a number of seminars and meetings to introduce project activities and the liskt of kind donations provided by the project to encourage the spread of the technology.
The project signed a cooperation protocol with the Faculty of Agriculture, Menya University, on August 30, 2014, to provide technical assistance and spread biogas technology among faculty students. The Faculty will assist the project in analyzing bio-fertilizer and provide best ways of using it in cultivation. The project will assist the faculty to use its kitchen waste for biogas generation.
One of the biggest private Egyptian factories ‘Universal’ is manufacturing the biogas stoves that are not available in the local market and which was only available in the two governorates targeted by the project; namely, Fayoum and Assuit. After the wide spread of the project, it is required to be available everywhere and extra stoves should be sell in the market.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: An enabling policy framework, effectively promoting rural bioenergy development, adopted.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: An enabling policy framework for promoting sustainable rural biomass energy adopted, including: recognition of BET and other renewable systems in official Government documents as the first option to be studied and considered for meeting rural energy needs, whenever technically and economically feasible

actual.comment: The cost-sharing of the project is an important factor in encouraging people to request more units, especially in the current context of rising fossil fuel prices. To continue the cost-sharing aspect of the project, a self-sustaining entity namely a Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association, is now developed and approved by Cabinet of Ministers to replace the project during its last quarter.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: A level playing field for BET systems to compete with subsidized fossil fuels created and, as applicable, introduction of eventual additional financial or fiscal incentives to support BETs on the basis of their socio-economic and environmental benefits

actual.comment:
A cooperation protocol was signed with Faculty of Agriculture, Menya University, on August 30, 2014, to provide technical assistance and spread biogas technology among faculty students. The Faculty will assist the project in analyzing bio-fertilizer and provide best ways of using it in cultivation. The project will assist the faculty to use its kitchen waste for biogas generation.
Cooperation is with the Small Grants Program to build the capacity of the granted NGOs by providing on-job training before helping their customers with biogas household units.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: A supportive regulatory framework for managing the relations between the bioenergy service providers and the customers; Adoption of adequate product standards and quality control mechanisms.

actual.comment: The batches of training have been completed with 16 engineers and masons who are already tested and certified as biogas household service providers. The project worked on registering them legally BSPs through hired legal consultants. The role of the BSPs is to provide a comprehensive service, starting from awareness, application collections, site visits, installing the units, monitoring the gas production, and providing after-sales services for at least one full year (with periodic visits to the units) to assure beneficiary satisfaction. The project has to date registered tewenty BSPs and will continue to register others

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Enhanced capacity of the local supply chain to market and deliver sustainable rural bioenergy products and services, including financing.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: At least 20 new local entities to serve as BSPs identified and their capacity built by the end of the first 18 months.

actual.comment:
Currently, political support for the project is high, stemming notably from the Decree of the Board of Governors as well as welcoming the establishment of the Bioenergy for Sustainable Rural Development Association as a centralized association representing legal entities that are members of the PSC.
The project opened channels with universities in different Governorates that support awareness workshops and set elective courses during the coming academic years to boost the labour pool available to the bio-energy technology (BET) sector.
BSPs started their work in different Governorates, with the support of the project either through the awareness campaigns or application collection by EEAA RBOs. First 2 batched of BSBs will receive on-job training on the biggest commercial biogas unit during the last quarter of the year.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: The follow-up activities and business of the trained BSPs show an increasing trend, leveraging financing from a variety of sources.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Institutionalization of the support provided by the project, including monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: An entity continuing the bioenergy market promotion after the project established and its funding secured

actual.comment:
For the household biogas units, there is now accurate financial data for units of different sizes, using materials prices from local markets and empirical labour wage (man-day) rates. This data also includes the cost of the bioslurry that is generated from the installed unit compared to the chemical fertilizers that farmers use on their lands. The project is using this data to design a Self-Sustaining Biomass Energy Entity: the study will be published early next year.
The main aim of this study is to prepare policy guidelines for the project cycle in line with the pre-set strategy and guiding principles, complete the financial feasibility analysis and relevant cash flow analysis with regards to the "fund's" operations and possible scenarios regarding leveraging available balances in the short and medium term, and developing a draft institutional set up for the potential fund for discussion with project stakeholders.

baseline.comment: Lack of supportive policies to create a level playing field for BETs.

target.comment: Required information available during the implementation of the project for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of project activities.

actual.comment: The project’s detailed database on the received requests for biogas unit installations, the installed units and full information of the after-sales services provided is now available on the project’s local server and is accessible to project staff and BSPs. This has contributed to a sense of openness and inclusiveness with regard to the BSPs, which has fostered goodwill; it has also made project tracking and information retrieval much more straightforward

result.title: Objective
result.description:
To reduce the growth of energy consumption and related greenhouse gas emissions of the transport sector in Egypt, while simultaneously mitigating the local environmental and other problems of increasing traffic such as deteriorating urban air quality and congestion (Indicator: the growth rate of transport sector energy consumption).
To create an enabling policy and institutional environment and leverage resources for sustainable transport sector development, including the increasing or sustained modal share of public and non-motorized transportation, reduced use of private cars and more energy efficient freight transportation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The status and impact of the pilot projects.

baseline.comment: The need for the proposed activities recognized, but the implementation suffering from different barriers.

target.comment: The proposed pilot activities successfully concluded with the associated reduction of CO2 emissions by 1.48 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities.

actual.comment:
1) The Ministers of Transport, Housing, Utilities, and Urban Development, Environment, and the newly-appointed Giza Governor expressed full commitment to the protocol signed by their ministries and Governorate for implementing the pilot project.
The contract of the Delegation of Authority from Giza Governorate to the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing for bidding, operating and monitoring the five bus lines has been signed by both parties in July 2014.
NUCA’s Board of Directors, chaired by Minister of Housing and including six Ministers approved the project and incentive packages to private sector with some comments that were integrated into the tendering documents. The tender for implementing the pilot project connecting Greater Cairo with its satellite cities (6 October, Sheikh Zayed, and Media Production / Dreamland Cities) with integrated, high-quality public transportation has been issued in December2014 by the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing.
Estimated CO2 reductions from this pilot after 10 years will be about 120,000 tones of CO2.
2) The newly-appointed Menofia Governor confirmed commitment to the protocol signed by his Governorate with the Ministry of Environment for implementing the pilot project of the non-motorized transport corridor in Shebin El Kom City in Menofia Governorate. Two construction contracts covering the construction of the cycling tracks in Shebin El-Kom City were signed in 2014/2105
.A protocol was signed in September 2014 by the Ministry of Environment and Fayoum Governorate for implementing the pilot project of the non-motorized transport corridor in Fayoum City in Fayoum. Two construction contracts were signed covering construction of the cycling tracks were signed in 2015
3) Cairo Governorate is fully committed to the protocol signed with the Ministry of Environment for implementing the pilot project of the Variable Message Parking Signs (VMPS) in Cairo City Centre. The pilot has been implemented, the system has been installed, soft opening / commissioning has taken place in May 2015 by the Prime Minister, Ministry of Environment, Cairo Governor and UNDP within the framework of a launching an LE 50 million integrated traffic monitoring and control system in Cairo City Center. The Governor of Cairo issued a decree to prohibit car parking in Cairo City Center main streets which promoted the use and added value for the Variable Message Sign System .
Estimated CO2 reductions from this pilot after 10 years are about 2,000 tones of CO2.
4) Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Interior are coordinating to implement a pilot project for establishing integrated centers for vehicles environmental and technical inspection in Cairo Governorate.
The emissions factors for gasoline engines have been used for the calculation of GHG emissions from the Transport Sector in Egypt.
5) Activities of the AFD / French GEF Project, "Support To An Improved Urban Transport System In Cairo", continue to be implemented in synergy with the UNDP-implemented, GEF-financed project under the same Project Management Unit.
The activities of the AFD Project under implementation include:
a) Pilot project for improving Cairo Transit Authority El Nasr Garage to be a Green Garage by improving the environmental performance (management and maintenance practices); and
b) Completed a study on estimation and modeling of factors governing emissions of CO2 and other air pollutants from the public transport modes using diesel engines including buses, mini buses, & micro buses in Greater Cairo which complements the study done earlier by the UNDP-GEF project thus covering all means of transport in Greater Cairo.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Level of replication and/or expansion of the sustainable transport schemes promoted by the project

target.comment: The replication of the projects initiated as per the stated replication targets, including the leveraging of financial resources for the amount of at least USD 100 million for their future implementation.

actual.comment:
Soft opening / commissioning of the Variable Message Parking Signs (VMPS) pilot in Cairo City Centre VMS has taken place, and Cairo Governorate intends to extend / replicate the system in other areas in Greater Cairo using the same project control room.
The pilot projects of the non-motorized transport corridor in Monofia and Fayoum are still under implementation, and they are expected to be completed during 3rd Quarter 2015. Ministry of Environment is coordinating with the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing for replicating the pilot after NUCA established a cycling lane in New Cairo adopting the same UNDP-GEF design and expressed plans to expand to the rest of the New Cities.
For replication, the project management is documenting the project pilot approaches, and the success stories after finalizing implementation any of the pilots, so as to present lessons-learned and recommended future options to the senior management of the relevant Government ministries. The project shall follow up closely to ensure that these options are inserted / integrated in the Ministries' future plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Level of adoption and implementation of the required policy and institutional changes

target.comment: The required policy and institutional development needs recognized and implemented by the Government.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The concept for new, integrated high-quality public transport services (to exert shift from private cars) for Cairo and its satellite cities successfully introduced and replicated on the basis of public-private partnerships.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The new public transport services continue to operate on a self-sustaining basis at the end of the project

baseline.comment: No adequate public transport services that can attract car users for the satellite cities available

target.comment: The new public transport services introduced during the project continue to operate on a self-sustaining basis.

actual.comment:
The project team completed all tendering documents for the pilot project to implement 3 new, high-quality public transportation bus services connecting Greater Cairo with 6th October City, Sheikh Zayed City, Media Production City / Dream Land to Metro line number 2 in Giza Governorate, as well as two feeder bus lines running in 6 October City and secured
The project team went through a long approval process for the tendering documents starting with technical staff then legal office in NUCA and ended up securing approval NUCA’s Board of Directors on the incentives package for the private sector given that it is the first contract of its type in Egypt.
The International tender was issued in December 2014 by the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) under the Ministry of Housing. The project team organized several meetings inviting interested private sector, businessmen associations, and commercial departments in Embassies to explain about the project
Several international and national companies / investors expressed interest and enthusiasm about the project and seven companies purchased the tender documents, but no proposals were received before the deadline which reflects private sector concerns given that the project is implemented in Egypt for the first time.
Project team in coordination with NUCA has conducted a series of meetings with the companies / investors to better understand their concerns about the tender. Accordingly, some modifications were introduced to the tender documents including an additional incentives for the investors, and retendering of the pilot project expected in July 2015.
2) The pilot project for executing a feeder bus public transportation system serving Saraya El Koba and Maadi Metro stations is still on hold by Cairo Governorate until the new Agency for Regulating Urban Transport in Greater Cairo, established under the Ministry of Transport, becomes operational. The Agency mandate in relation to Cairo Transit Authority (CTA) mandate still has to be specified and announced.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Proposals and agreements for replication are submitted and negotiated with the relevant authorities

baseline.comment: No feeder system that can attract car users for metro in place

target.comment: Agreements for the replication of the concept of new, high quality and integrated (with citiesâ€™ internal public transport systems) inter-city bus services between Cairo and its 6 satellite cities formulated and discussed with the authorities

actual.comment: Proposals and agreements for replicating the establishment of new, high quality and integrated public bus transportation services connecting Cairo with its satellite cities will be formulated and discussed with the authorities in parallel with the pilot project implementation during Q4 2015. Nevertheless, NUCA is currently negotiating with EBRD to design new public transport bus lines and BRT system within 6 of October City to expand applications of the new contract after being tested in UNDP-GEF project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the pilot projects compared to the baseline

baseline.comment: Lack of experience with more advanced, road-based public transport systems such as BRT.

target.comment: Successful demonstration and agreement of the Government for replication of an integrated feeder bus and ticketing system for 9 existing and for 5 new metro stations in Cairo.

actual.comment:
Demonstration and agreement with the Government for replication of the integrated feeder bus and ticketing system for Metro stations in Greater Cairo will start in parallel with the pilot project implementation during Q4 2015.
Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Housing, and Giza Governorate are very supportive of the concept / objectives of the pilot project for connecting the new cities with Greater Cairo via high-quality public transportation bus services integrated with the Metro lines, and they are planning to replicate this approach on a larger scale in their future plans.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: The modal share of non-motorized transport in middle-size provincial cities increased or sustained.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Modal share of NMT in the targeted cities

baseline.comment: 52% in Shebin El-Kom (down from 68% in 1988) and 31% in Fayoum

target.comment: The estimated current NMT modal share in the targeted cities sustained or increased

actual.comment:
1) Menofia Governorate has contributed with more than LE 20 million for developing and upgrading the infrastructure and the utilities in the network of roads of the NTM pilot project against LE 4 million from STP which exceeded the 50% requested contribution of Menofia Governorate. The pilot project in Menofia is under implementation, and most of the construction activities in the 6 corridors have been completed .
2) Co-funding of the pilot project in Fayoum was provided by the Egyptian Social Fund for Development (SFD) with L.E 2.6 million as part of the local contribution according to the protocol signed between Fayoum Governorate and SFD, and that part has been implemented and construction activities have been completed. Remaining activities of the pilot in Fayoum, with an estimated total cost of about L.E 5.4 million, has been tendered for construction in November 2014, the winning company has been contracted, and construction is progressing well.
3) The project continued coordinating with the GEF Small Grants Programme (SGP) in Egypt in the context of organizing and following-up on the participation of the local NGOs (three NGOs from Menofia and two from Fayoum) signed Memorandums of Agreement with SGP in implementing some of the pilot project activities in Menofia and Fayoum Governorates. The total of GEF SGP grants for the 5 NGOs is approximately $200,000. The NGOs in Menofia and Fayoum with full support of the STP have been implementing intensive awareness campaigns in the 1st and 2nd Quarter 2015 according to the detailed plan for implementing these campaigns agreed on by SGP, STP, EEAA,UNDP and the local authorities in the 2 Governorates. The SGP has also established a revolving funds to support youth buying bicycles and initiated installation of cycling parking racks all over the two cities.
Results achieved to date are a good indicator for the PMU that the pilot NMT corridors are regarded as an urban development initiative that supports behavioral change; accordingly, it is envisaged that the corridors will enable the project, by 2015, to achieve its target for sustaining / increasing the modal share of NMT.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of kilometres of new NMT corridors constructed and used

target.comment: A total of 50km of new NMT corridors constructed and used by the end of the project

actual.comment: The NMT corridors that have been constructed in Menofia Governorate covers a length of 14 km. Similarly, in Fayoum Governorate, the NMT corridors under construction will also cover a length of 14 Kms . The total length of the NMT corridors in Menofia and Fayoum is therefore about 28 km.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the selected pilot projects compared to the baseline.

target.comment: Reduced CO2 emissions of 0.26 million tons of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities

actual.comment: The CO2 emissions to be reduced as a direct result of the project activities will be estimated in Q4 2015. The CO2 emission reductions have not yet been achieved and the future expected reductions will be known within 6 months of the operation of the NMT corridors.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Successful introduction of the Transport Demand Management (TDM) concept with an objective to expand it towards more aggressive measures over time to effectively discourage the use of private cars, when good quality public transport services are available.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The level of enforcement of the piloted TDM measures

baseline.comment: No real strategy currently in place to effectively proceed with TDM in order to reduce local air pollution and congestion in Greater Cairo area and Alexandria and simultaneously contribute to GHG reduction

target.comment: The pilot TDM measures effectively enforced and respected by car users

actual.comment:
1) Concerning the TDM pilot project for applying a bus priority system at traffic signals in Moustafa El Nahas Corridor is still on hold as Cairo Governorate did not approve tendering the design, supply, installation and maintenance of the transit priority system. Cairo Governorate has been working on developing the whole Moustafa El Nahas Corridor, and constructed a segregated bus lane.
2) The TDM pilot project for introducing Variable Message Parking Signs (VMS) to guide cars to the appropriate parking facilities around the City Centre in Cairo Governorate has been implemented by a consortium of Italian / Egyptian companies in coordination with Cairo Governorate authorities. A high-level committee chaired by Cairo Governorate Secretary General, and with the participation of high government officials from Cairo Governorate, UNDP, EEAA, project management and experts has been meeting intensively to follow up on the progress of implementing the pilot, and to solve problems that might cause delay.
The VMS system includes 14 signs in the surroundings of the City Centre connected with 10 parking areas.
The consortium of the Italian / Egyptian companies that was contracted to implement the pilot has conducted the following activities:
- Field surveys and investigations to identify the existing utilities in the VMS locations;
- Manufacturing the components of the VMS system in Italy, and transporting it to Egypt;
- Civil, mechanical and electrical works for installing and operating the VMS system; and
- Install the equipment in the Operation Control Center (OCC).
A committee from representatives of the Ministry of Environment / EEAA, Cairo Governorate, project management and experts has attended and approved the Factory Acceptance Test (FAT) conducted in Italy in December 2014 on the different components of the VMS system, and the Site Acceptance Test (SAT) conducted in Cairo in May 2015 on the VMS system after being installed.
Cairo Governorate has provided and furnished a center to be used for the operation control of the VMS system.
The pilot project has been implemented, and the system installed in full coordination with Cairo Governorate
Soft opening / commissioning has taken place in May 2015 by the Prime Minister, Ministry of Environment, Cairo Governor and UNDP. Fine tuning and testing of the system is going on.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: The level of satisfaction of the key stakeholders on the effectiveness of the TDM measures introduced

target.comment: High satisfaction of the key stakeholders on the effectiveness of the TDM measures introduced and on the quality of the alternative public transport services provided

actual.comment:
1) The TDM pilot project for applying bus priority system at traffic signals in Moustafa El Nahas Corridor has been put on hold by Cairo Governorate as it has been studying the integration of that system with the development of the whole Moustafa El Nahas Corridor, that included a segregated bus lane that Cairo Governorate has constructed in the corridor.
2) The TDM pilot project for introducing variable message parking signs (VMS) to guide cars to the appropriate parking facilities around the city centre in Cairo Governorate has been implemented, and commissioning of the system took place. In fast survey, car owners over Facebook expressed satisfaction with the new system.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: The estimated amount of reduced GHG emissions by the selected pilot projects compared to the baseline

target.comment: Agreement of the local governments to replicate and/or expand the pilot TDM measures in the Greater Cairo Area and, if applicable, Alexandria

actual.comment: After the successful implementation of the variable message parking signs (VMS) pilot project, Cairo Governorate is studying the possibility to extend the VMS system to other parts in Cairo. The VMS system was designed to accommodate more signs inside and outside Cairo that can be managed through the same control room.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Improved energy efficiency of freight transport

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Fuel consumption and the associated GHG emissions per ton and km of goods transported

baseline.comment: Inefficient operation of the existing truck fleet

target.comment: Reduced CO2 emissions of 0.85 million tons of CO2 equivalent (calculated for the pilot projects over 20 years from the project start) as a direct result of the project activities

actual.comment:
The Ministries of Environment and Interior (MoI) have been working together to implement a pilot project for issuing licenses to the private sector specialized companies to establish integrated centers in Cairo Governorate for vehicles technical and environmental inspection for issuing / renewing licenses of these vehicles.
Also, there was coordination between the MoI and the United Arab Emirates Government for providing technical and financial support for the design and construction of these centers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Fuel consumption and the associated GHG emissions per ton and km of goods transported

baseline.comment: Low utilization of the available rail and river based freight transport options

target.comment: Over 100,000 tons savings in fuel consumption as a result of the project activities by the end of the project.

actual.comment: Discussions have been ongoing between the Ministries of Environment and Transport on the appropriate sustainable transport measures to be adopted by the Ministry of Transport and can be supported by the project, according to the report prepared by the project with recommendations to improve national freight transport on road, rail and river.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Strengthened institutional capacity to promote sustainable transport sector development during and after the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The progress with the institutional reforms and other improvements needed

baseline.comment: The level of awareness and capacity of the key stakeholders as well as the level of adoption and implementation of the required legal, regulatory and institutional changes to facilitate sustainable transport sector development still low

target.comment: For all outcomes: Adoption of a national, sustainable transport policy addressing the key requirements and setting concrete short, medium and long term targets in different key areas the project is addressing

actual.comment:
The project has analyzed the results of the field measurements conducted and the huge data-set collected in the field study for determination of the fuel-based emission factors of private cars and taxis with gasoline engines in Greater Cairo, and has continued the study to determine the emission factors based on travel distance of the cars (g/km) - i.e. activity-based emission factors. The generated emission factors were integrated in the Third National Communication Report to UNFCCC for Egypt. The project has used the on-board measurements to construct a local drive cycle representing the traffic pattern in Greater Cairo, which has been used to estimate activity-based emission factors.
A training was organized for the relevant staff in the Environmental Agency on the data acquisition and analysis for estimating the emission factor The “Support To An Improved Urban Transport System in Cairo” Project funded by AFD / French GEF (also managed by the UNDP-GEF Project Management Unit) has continued conducting a complementary field study for determination of fuel-based emission factors of diesel engine vehicles (buses, minibuses and micro buses) under local driving conditions in Greater Cairo using on-board measuring equipment.

target.comment: For Outcome 1: Enhanced capacity of the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies in the area of sustainable transport to effectively co-ordinate the development of the public transport systems in Cairo and other major urban centers in Egypt.

actual.comment:
1) The Project / EEAA has been coordinating with the new Agency for Regulating Urban Transport in Greater Cairo, under the Ministry of Transport, to investigate the opportunities to assist in building its capacity, and developing its organization.
2) The Project / EEAA has also being coordinating with the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies (river, rail authorities and the General Authority for Roads, Bridges and Land Transport, GARBLT) to investigate the opportunities to assist in building their capacity in the area of sustainable transport to effectively co-ordinate the development of the public transport systems in Cairo and other major urban centers in Egypt.

target.comment: For Outcome 2: The non-motorized transport (NMT) modal share in Fayoum and Shebin El Kom cities sustained or increased, and the capacity of the local authorities in the 2 Governorates enhanced to develop and implement NMT. Social acceptance of cycling, and NMT supply side services in the 2 cities increased.

actual.comment:
The project has developed a Communication and Environmental Awareness program that are being executed in cooperation with the GEF Small Grants Programme (SGP) in Egypt via SGP-funded NGOs.
The partner NGOs in Shebin El-Kom and Fayoum held two public largecycling events, marking the beginning of the pilot projects and the awareness campaign. The events helped to introduce the STP and its pilots to the broad community and the media.
The project launched awareness campaign on cycling and walking in parallel in the two cities with the initiation of the construction works. Several cycling events were organized in the two cities with participation of senior officials from the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Youth and Sport and the respective Governorate. Cycling events attracted hundreds of youth in the two cities. Bicycles were offered as awards to a number of youth who participated in the events and Ministry of Social Solidarity offered down payments for new bicycles for 100 people. Cyclists groups from Cairo and Alexandria were invited to participate and share experience with the newly established cyclist groups in the two cities.
Several awareness-raising seminars have been conducted by the NGOs in cooperation with the project team over the period from January-June 2015. Four seminars in Fayoum, and three in Menofia were held targeting school and university students, youths, women, workers as well as bus and taxi drivers. Over 450 persons attended the different seminars in Fayoum, and more than 850 persons in Shebin El-Kom. The project is currently preparing awareness videos that will be used by the NGOs in the seminars.
A public awareness campaign under the name "Let's Cycle for a Better Community" was launched in January through June 2015 . The campaign aims to raise the social acceptance of cycling and to lower the barriers to bicycle purchase and use in the two governorates, where the STP Pilots are being implemented.
The project encouraged the partner NGOs to establish amateur cycling groups in their governorates. The newly established groups in the two cities started activities with creating their Facebook pages and organizing several rides occasionally.To further support the new cycling groups,STP provided the groups with the opportunity to do joint activities with professional cycling groups and participate in their events in Cairo and Alexandria.
The project also continued coordinating with the Swedish Institute in Alexandria and the Green Arm of Nahdat El-Mahrousa NGO to support the cycling and walking campaigns that the project is conducting.
The successful implementation of the pilot project activities will help in increasing the social acceptance of cycling and will enhance the supply of supporting services such as trade, maintenance and repair of bicycles, and encourage the local authorities in the two Governorates to replicate them in other provincial cities. It will also lead to an increase of the NMT modal share in the two Governorates.
The local authorities in the two Governorates are fully supporting the implementation of the pilots, and provided their contributions to the construction cost.

target.comment: For Outcome 3: Subject to the agreement with the local authorities, a semi-public parking authority to implement and, in close collaboration with other key authorities, to enforce parking policies (conducive to sustainable transport sector development principles), if possible, established by the end of the project and its capacity built.

actual.comment: The frequent change in senior government officials since 2011,has made it difficult to set up new institutional and regulatory frameworks for parking policies in Cairo’s Central Business District (CBD). That was discussed with the Evaluator in the Mid-Term Review conducted in 2012 and it was agreed to cancel this output.

target.comment: For Outcome 4: Enhanced capacity of the Ministry of Transport and its underlying agencies to develop and implement sustainable transport policies and actions in the field of freight transport

actual.comment:
1) Project experts continued to provide technical support and enhance the capacity of the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency (EEAA) technical staff concerning sustainable transport, vehicle emissions factors, vehicles emissions and control.
2) The project has been preparing a training programme for the local authority officials and engineers in the main cities for building their capacity in integrated urban land use and transport planning for sustainable passenger transport and sustainable freight transport. The training programme shall be conducted in Q4 2015.

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The required information available for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities

baseline.comment: Inadequate information for adaptive management, for measuring the impact and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities

target.comment: The required information available for adaptive management, for measuring the impact of the project and for effective replication/expansion of the project activities

actual.comment:
In spite of the many changes in the positions of senior government officials in recent years, the project succeeded to get all required political support, to renew the approvals of the new senior officials in Ministries and Governorates for the pilot projects, and to get their commitment for providing the local contribution in the implementation cost of the pilots.
All pilot projects have been under implementation, except the pilot connecting Greater Cairo with its satellite cities with integrated, high-quality public transportation shall be retendered in July 2015.
Construction of the NMT pilot in Menofia Governorate has nearly been completed, and VMS pilot in Cairo Governorate has been implemented and commissioned.
In light of the political stability over the last year, the project has pursued an adaptive strategy through 2014 / 2015, in which the project management continued to exert efforts to sign protocols with the relevant authorities for implementing the remaining pilot projects, in which commitment and responsibilities of all parties / stakeholders were identified and agreed on. Also, to expedite implementation of all pilot projects, and to have big percentage of the construction works completed during 1st half of 2015.

baseline.comment: Baseline: Existing HR system needs to be updated Baseline: Limited RBM and other development trainings conducted to SFD Baseline: No automated enterprise wide information system in place Baseline: No UNDP Exit Strategy in place Baseline: Existing internal manual for operational and project implementation procedures for SFD need to be reviewed Baseline: Limited number of change management recommendation are implemented Baseline: No RBM readiness assessment previously conducted

target.comment: • Results-based staff performance appraisal systems developed and implemented • Capacity of SFD staff at central and regional level enhanced in all development related subjects with special emphasis on results-based management (RBM) • Comprehensive plan developed to mainstream RBM into SFD systems, procedures & management

actual.comment: • Updated HR systems and updated SFD salary scale and package of benefits and performance based on staff appraisal system. • SFD started a comprehensive skills upgrading program for its staff at regional and central level: around 721 of SFD staff were trained during 2014 on business-related subjects. • UNDP support to SFD in the area of RBM and gender has allowed SFD to mainstream RBM into systems to provide improved pro-poor, inclusive and gender sensitive policies. 29 processes were automated with all related reports and modification for the system's compatibility.

target.comment: • Enhanced SFD's institutional and Operational efficiency: o Train Staff. o Internally audit projects. o Automate some processes.

actual.comment: • 377 Staff where trained and The Central Sector for Internal Audit audited an aggregate of 925 projects nationwide; 340 Micro Finance, 30 Small Enterprises and 412 Community Development projects. • 7 processes were automated as follow: 1-SFD Alert 2- Evaluation Close Procedure 3-Alert For Regional Offices arrears 4- Fund management Module 5- Upgrade First Trial of Financial Module from 11.5.9 to 12.0.0 6-Training Module For Human Development Projects. 7- Completed trial 1 and processing the final stage in upgrading the financial module.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1- million LE disbursed to fund small enterprise projects (disaggregated by gender) 2- million LE disbursed to fund micro enterprise projects (disaggregated by gender) 3- # of small enterprises funded 4- # of micro enterprises funded 5- # of beneficiaries received non-financial services 6- # of entrepreneurship training programs designed and delivered 7- # of potential entrepreneurs who benefited from SFD entrepreneurship training program. 8- # of new non-financial products developed and adopted 9- # of national exhibitions conducted/ sponsored by SFD 10- Credit risk management study in place

baseline.comment: Baseline: 1279 million LE disbursed to fund small enterprise projects (273 million disbursed to fund projects led by women) Baseline: 472 million LE disbursed to fund micro enterprise projects (193 million LE disbursed to fund projects led by women) Baseline: 18112 small enterprises funded (4685 projects female owned) Baseline: 127000 micro enterprises funded (65.000 projects female owned) Baseline: around 47249 beneficiaries received non-financial services Baseline: 27 entrepreneurship training programs designed and delivered Baseline: 1643 potential entrepreneurs who benefited from SFD entrepreneurship training program. Baseline: 9 of new non-financial products developed and adopted Baseline: 45 national exhibitions conducted/ sponsored by SFD Baseline: no credit risk management study in place

target.comment: Networking connection between OSS branches and Line ministries established • Improve financial and non-financial services for MSEs • Increase access of poor women to financial and non-financial services • Improve Gender Mainstreaming in SFD

actual.comment:
• Financial and non-financial services:  13,942 Financed small enterprises created an estimate of 55,974 jobs.  143,310 Financed micro enterprises created an estimate of 132,710 jobs.  1464 trainees benefited from SFD Entrepreneurship training programs  63 training programs were delivered  6 new non-financial service programs were conducted and completed.  62 local exhibitions, 45 regional exhibitions were organized where approx.1259 small enterprises displayed their products.
• Increased access of poor women to services, finance resources and assets in Egypt:  SFD worked on cash-for-works projects in labour-intensive social services for women and youth in disadvantaged communities in 4 governorates e.g. school feeding in Behiera (19,725 workdays); Hepatitis C Virus awareness campaigns in Luxor, Assiut and Sohag (112,500 workdays).  In terms of lending, out of an aggregate of 13,942 small enterprises financed 22.5 % are female owned while out of an aggregate of 143,310 microenterprises, 46.1 % are female owned.
• Gender mainstreaming:  Established a gender Unit within SFD and recruited a team.  Established a Gender Focal Team (GFT) within SFD headed by the Head of non-financial services central sector.  Conducted a self-assessment on gender gaps based on UNDP Gender Seal frameworks.  Drafted a Gender Strategy for SFD and currently working on finalizing the strategy and the action plan.  Held 2 training sessions for the GFT members on gender analysis  8 of SFD staff received TOT training with ILO on curriculum called (WEGROW) for women entrepreneurs and certified as trainers from ILO (2 persons from GFT).

target.comment: • Improve financial and non-financial services for MSEs • Increase access of poor women to financial and non-financial services • Improve Gender Mainstreaming in SFD

actual.comment:
• Finance for Small enterprises: SFD financed a total of 15,211 small enterprises (78% male-owned, 22% female-owned) in loans disbursing an aggregate of 2,270.2 million EGP to companies working in sectors of industry, trade, services, agriculture and others.
• Finance for Micro-enterprises: SFD financed a total of 152,891 micro-businesses (57% male-owned; 43% female-owned) in loans disbursing an aggregate of 1,170.9 million EGP.
• Non-financial services:
o SFD organized 52 local exhibitions for businesses to display their products.
o It provided tailored services for MSEs through the operation of its 33 One-Stop-Shops throughout the country and provided training and support in industrial, entrepreneurship and marketing activities.
o A total of 72 training programmes were organized and 2,198 trainees benefited from SFD's entrepreneurship training.
• Gender mainstreaming: o A gender unit has been established under SFD since mid 2014 with institutional support from UNDP using the corporate framework of achieving a certified gender seal. o A dedicated unit has established a gender focal team and carried out a series of training for HQ and regional staff. o The unit has also been instrumental in mainstreaming gender equality and women's empowerment throughout SFD's financial and non-financial projects and activities. o It has also carried out a number of Women Entrepreneurs Days in Cairo and in regional offices (Luxor, Aswan) to share success stories of women entrepreneurs, display their products and promote networking with stakeholders. o SFD is finalizing a Gender strategy which will be launched by Q1 2016.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Center established and PS companies are registered for training Arabic material on CSR available CSR training organized based on international standards

baseline.comment: No body to coordinate CSR activities in the country No scientific way to go about designing CSR stategies Lack of Arabic material on CSR

target.comment: • Conferences conducted to launch the CSR financial, agricultural and textiles sectors reports • Training courses conducted based on the findings of the reports • Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) sustainability reporting training conducted for 25 companies from the 3 sectors • CSR training conducted for journalists • 4 Global Compact roundtables organized

actual.comment: • Egyptian Corporate Responsibility Center (ECRC) supported the formulation and capacity building program around three CSR Sector diagnostics in the financial, textile and agriculture sectors. • 10 awareness sessions and training workshops were conducted for the Financial and Agro-food Sectors, according to the recommendation of each sector study. Textile sessions were not conducted. • ECRC coordinated two journalists’ trainings on CSR. The first one was attended by 14 journalists from the different national newspapers while the second one was attended by 12 participants. • ECRC continued to support the local UN Global Compact Network in Egypt attracting over 90 signatories. In 2014, 30 independent and specialized work streams focused on the role of businesses in relation to various GC principles. For human rights, around 5 awareness sessions and capacity building trainings were organized for 20 participants from different organizations. For labour rights, 4 sessions were organized for 15 participants, 3 sessions for environment with 20 participants and for anti-corruption, 2 capacity building programs for approximately 15 participants.

target.comment: • To Organize training program on Social Return on Investment (SROI) • Promote Social Entrepreneurship Program. • Manage the second edition of the Business Solutions for Human Development Report. • Improve the gender balance of corporate boards in Egypt. • Expand the Global Compact network activities to be a sustainable body

actual.comment:
• The first training program on Social Return on Investment (SROI) was organized by ECRC to encourage social development practices in Egypt. • ECRC worked on Social Entrepreneurship Program in which it developed an outstandingly effective program on the development of Egypt’s local talents featured in the “Creative Egypt” event which was held at the Furnex exhibition in Egypt & turned to be the Home for Local Talents. • ECRC managed the second edition of the Business Solutions for Human Development Report to reinforce that the private sector in Egypt can engage the poor & play a role in poverty reduction while making profits. • ECRC in collaboration with AUC & IFC worked on the Women on Boards initiative (WOB) to improve the gender balance of corporate boards in Egypt through multiple interventions.
• Global Compact in Egypt organized: - In-focus events on the 4 basic pillars of the UNGC (Human Rights, Labor, Environment & Anti-Corruption). - 2 training Sessions on Communication on Progress (COP) & 3 Training Sessions on Communication on Engagement (COE) Report making. - Internship for 25 undergraduates on COP/COE supporting services and report making. • GC retained 29 members and actively recruited 22 new participants to network. • GC formed Partnership with international organizations (Un agencies, AIESEC international, GIZ, and work environment foundation). • GC formed Partnership with ECONOWIN to promote gender diversity at work place. • ECRC supported the launch of the GC network in Tunis and has hosted in Egypt the MENA GC regional meeting. The Regional meeting offered the platform for the different local networks to share experience and exchange information.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: Establishment of a sustainable protected area financing system, with associated management structures, systems and capacities needed to ensure the effective use of generated revenues for priority biodiversity conservation needs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Level and diversity of financing for the PA system

baseline.comment:
Financing of protected areas is below 20% of basic scenario
Only two predominant sources (government and tourism) in use

target.comment:
At project end, achieved levels of revenue are within 10% of projection and the trend in growth rates sets the NCS on track to meet the optimal scenario by year 10[1]
At least two new, reliable sources of funds are established

actual.comment:
According to the official reports on financing of PA system during reporting year, a general indicator shows remarkable progress where $2.5m was allocated as a governmental budget and $1.7m was allocated to PAs as co-sharing for the project toward optimal scenario of PA management.
In cooperation with “Support protected Areas” project, under Italian cooperation, $ 0.5m was allocated for upgrading the PAs infrastructure, equipments and staff capacities.
Financial reports of NCS show that PA revenues generated during 2015 is approx. $9 million including PAs entrance fees and concessions and
Two new management systems were prepared (Northern Red Sea Islands and Wadi Degla Protected Areas); the eight priority PAs now all use a consistent format.
The management system plans for the eight priority PAs were revised (including the overall management strategy, work plans and budgets) to align with NCS’s new Strategic Plan (2014).
Four management system plans have been submitted to NCS for revision, and four are remaining. They will all be revised until approved by EEAA. Once approved, the project can ensure allocation of the set budget from both EEAA and the project budget.
A Concession Committee has been founded to prepare the RFPs for any concession projects (touristic activities/vistor center) within three PAs (Wadi Rayan, Wadi Degla and Wadi El Gemal) and this will generate revenues of $2.2 million over 10 years and will be re-evaluated after 10 years, which will be proposed for bidding.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Levels of live coral coverage in dive sites and non-dive sites

baseline.comment: Most Red Sea dive sites are being degraded by heavy and careless diving

target.comment:
No significant degradation measured in new dive sites to be opened to special seasonal tourists
Degradation in old dive sites does not increase

actual.comment: A monitoring workshop was prepared during which target species for each ecosystem were selected, and an action plan was prepared to monitor them. Two meetings were held to discuss these documents and introduce the prepared monitoring manuals for the selected target species. The monitoring of most target species took place without follow-up; this year, monitoring of all target species will take place with aid from EPASP, SEPA and NCS and the results of coral reef monitoring will be gathered.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Flagship species at priority PAs

baseline.comment:
Flagship species at several priority PAs have been declining, including: (species to be defined):
Ras Mohamed PA: corals (Acropora, Pocillipora and Millipora ), Reptiles (Green turtle, Logger head), Mammals (Dugong dugong and Dorcas gazelle),

target.comment: Flagship species in PAs of terrestrial biomes recover or maintained, including:

actual.comment:
The integrated monitoring program training took place whereEight action plans were developed to monitor 5 groups of target species, including reptiles (Nile crocodile, ), plants (Typhadomingensis, Capparisspinosa, Avicennia marina), birds, mammals (Cape hare, Swamp cat, Egyptian mongoose, Dorcas gazelle, Nubian ibex, Barbary sheep), coral reef (including bio-indicator fishes and coral, Marine turtles, mangroves, sea grass, sea cucumber, algae, dolphins, shark, dugong).
Monitoring manuals were also prepared for each group of species; these manuals will be used as guidelines for any researcher to monitor any of these species.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Outcome 1: Policy, regulatory and institutional frameworks that facilitate revenue generation, revenue retention and other aspects of sustainable PA financing and management are established and operational

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National PA financing strategy

baseline.comment: No strategy

target.comment: Comprehensive 5-year financing strategy, including a financial needs assessment defining targets, standards, procedures and criteria for resource allocation, is approved at ministerial level by end of year 2

actual.comment: According to PAs financing strategy 10 million L.E ($1.5 m) were allocated to support the implementation of 5 PAs management systems which has been approved by the minister of Environment.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Institutional arrangements

baseline.comment: Ad-hoc arrangements

target.comment: Explicit policies and procedures to negotiate, monitor and implement institutional arrangements with business and social actors

actual.comment:
NCS’s Strategic Plan of 2014-2019 was implemented and all PA documents were changed accordingly (e.g. Management Systems)
The establishment of NCA has been accepted. A minister memo was submitted in hopes of receiving an official letter stating that the NCA will indeed take place so that the project’s activities are in line with the governmental institution.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Financial arrangements for revenue re-injection

baseline.comment: Generated revenues are co-mingled with revenues from other sources and allocations to NCS are ad-hoc and minimal

target.comment: Internal registry system (accounting system) for NCS established within EPF, accounting for revenues generated and disbursements, by end of project inception period.

actual.comment: Financial arrangements for revenue re-injection were done through Ministerial approval on allocation for PAs based on the management systems of targeted PAs which have been conducted by the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Policy regarding re-injection

baseline.comment: No policies to guide level of re-injection

target.comment: Revenue re-injection: A Ministerial Decree establishing a 10-year policy of achieving an optimal financing scenario largely through re-injected revenues.

actual.comment: The financial plans of the target PAs were reviewed based on NCS’s new strategic plan and integrated into their respective Management Plans. The budgets were approved by the Minister of Environment and also split between two types of funds (NCS funds and the project’s funds from Ministry of planning).

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Institutional structure and human capacities

baseline.comment: Minimal human capacities or institutional structure to address issues of financial sustainability

target.comment: Financial sustainability unit established at Headquarters level

actual.comment:
The following trainings took place for PA financial and managerial staff:
- PAs Financial Affairs
- Economic Valuation of Ecosystem Services
- Organizational Behavior & Recruitment & Selection
A guide was also prepared on PAs Financial Affairs for PA financial and managerial staff.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Legal and regulatory framework

actual.comment:
65% - 62 out of 95,
Economic valuation studies are being developed for Desert ecosystem at WRPA and for marine ecosystem at Ras Mohamed in 2015.
A comprehensive guide of the different types of permits within PAs and their value was prepared and accredited by NCS.
A concession committee was founded to review and write the RFPs for new concession activities within Wadi El Rayan and Wadi El Degla PAs.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2: Levels of financial resource mobilization are adequate to ensure effective conservation-oriented management of Egyptâ€™s PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Improved financial sustainability for PAs, as measured by the Financial Sustainability Scorecard
Business planning
Tools for revenue generation

baseline.comment: 2005-2008 annual average of $3.7 million USD

target.comment: Revenues generated by PA system over 6-year project duration total approximately $74 milllion with final exact figures depending on final financial needs assessments and basic and optimal scenarios

actual.comment: The total revenues generated by PAs system in 2012-2015 is approximately $19 million

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Revenues re-injected

baseline.comment: 2005-2008 annual average of $595,000

target.comment: Revenues re-injected into PA system over 6-year project duration total approximately $53 million, with final exact figures depending on final financial needs assessments and basic and optimal scenarios

actual.comment: Revenues re-injected into PA system over 4-years of the project total $17.94 million. In 2015 the total revenues re-injected into PA system was about US$ 4.7 million including (2.5 Gov + 0.5 external projects + 1.5 Gov/investment projects + 0.2 EPF).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Diversified revenues

baseline.comment: 95% of revenues generated by fees; Entrance fees at Ras Mohamed generating 53% of total system revenues

target.comment:
At least 25 % of revenues are being generated by sources other than user fees
No single site generating more than 40% of PA system revenues

actual.comment:
Number of concession projects have been approved by EEAA CEO to be implemented within three PAs (Wadi Rayan, Wadi Degla and Wadi El Gemal) which will increase generated revenues from different sources such as (Partnership with private sector, touristic and agricultural projects)
A commercial services plan is being developed in for WRPA and Wadi Degla.
The WGPA Visitor’s Center has been opened for bidding and is estimated to generate approximately 5 million LE over 10 years. The RFP for activities in Wadi Degla and Wadi El Rayan are being reviewed by the new concessions board.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3: Business planning and cost-effective management systems are ensuring the effective allocation and management of mobilized resources

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: METT Scores

baseline.comment: Baseline scores

target.comment: Improved management effectiveness in eight PAs altogether covering 1.85 million ha., as follows:

actual.comment: METT has been developed in two new PAs (Wadi Degla and Red Sea Northern Islands) along with its respective Management System, as well as in two untargeted PAs: Siwa, with a baseline score of 56% and Omayed with a baseline score of 43%.

baseline.comment: Ras Mohamed 69

target.comment: Ras Mohamed 85

actual.comment: Ras Mohamed – 64: METT score at RMNP shows improvement at management effectiveness through implementing development plan for attraction sites for visitors and providing number of trainings for raising the capacity of the park rangers.

baseline.comment: Wadi El-Gemal/Hamata 64

target.comment: Wadi El-Gemal/Hamata 85

actual.comment: Wadi El-Gemal/Hamata – 76

baseline.comment: Wadi-el Rayan 69

actual.comment: Wadi El-Rayan – 60

actual.comment: St. Katherine – 60: METT score at SKP shows improvement at management effectiveness through supporting visitors facilities at the park and raising the capacity of the park rangers through conducting of number of technical training.

target.comment: White Desert 75

actual.comment: White Desert – 64

target.comment: Nabq 80

Wadi Degla – 35
Governmental budget allocation is not enough to cover the PA’s financial needs, and has recently declined.

actual.comment: Red Sea Northern Islands - 42: METT score at RSNI shows significant decline at PA management as a result of lack of allocated budget and replaced of many of PA staff.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Business planning

baseline.comment:
Business plans in 2-3 sites, but not operational
Management plans in several sites, but lacking funds for implementation

target.comment:
By end of project, eight priority PAs are operated according to a full and consistent set of business and management planning tools
Standardized, high quality

actual.comment:
3 commercial services plans are in place where two new plans is being developed in Wadi Degla and Wadi El Rayan PAs . The TOR was prepared and uploaded to UNDP’s international website.
Two new management systems were developed in 2015 (Wadi Degla and Red Sea Northern Islands) with approximately all PAs staff present. The remaining six management plans were reviewed with PA managers to match the new NCS strategic plan. All the management systems were changed to a standard format and the financial plans were reviewed by an NCS financial planner. In addition, four other financial plans were reviewed by a UNDP financial intern. NCS has reviewed four management plans and made minor edits; those and the remaining four are estimated to be approved by NCS this year.
One new Economic valuation study is being developed for Wadi El Rayan, and another is being redeveloped for Ras Mohamed PA.
The project also participated in the Economic Forum in March of 2015 where the possible investments within PAs were presented, as well as organizing a workshop for tour guides and tour operators in Egypt.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Alternative management

baseline.comment: Ad-hoc arrangements

target.comment: Community partnership system tested in at least one PA

actual.comment: The project helped local communities participate in four bazaars and forums in Cairo by selling natural and organic products using the natural carton casing and wrapping developed during last year’s workshop. Local communities from Wadi El Rayan, Wadi El Gemal, Saint Katherine and Siwa participated. The project was able to convince local communities in Siwa to send women to stand in the booths and sell their own products (most of the products sold, especially those from WGPA, Saint Katherine and Siwa are produced by women).

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description: Accounting, audit, reporting

baseline.comment: Systems in place do not reach international standards

target.comment: International standards systems in place by end of project

actual.comment:
The following trainings took place for PA financial and managerial staff:
- PAs Financial Affairs
- Economic Valuation of Ecosystem Services
- Organizational Behavior & Recruitment & Selection
A guide was also prepared on PAs Financial Affairs for PA financial and managerial staff.
