result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: to integrate the management of SLR risks into the development of Egyptâ€™s Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) in the Nile Delta

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Enhanced resilience of Nile Delta coastal area on approximately 2,504 km2 due to adaptation measures (e.g. beach nourishment, vegetative buffers, sand placement and dune stabilization)

baseline.comment: North coasts of Egypt are characterized by high vulnerability to impacts of SLR. SLR will inundate land and coastal infrastructure and will also result in seawater intrusion will also further change the offshore water current patterns resulting in beach erosion and change in the shoreline which has its negative impact on tourism. SLR will also deteriorate coastal Mediterranean wetlands and induce stress on fisheries in the coastal lagoons. Furthermore, SLR. The government has been investing in â€œhardâ€ coastal protective measures that often diminish the robustness of the coast to anticipated SLR.

target.comment: At least three types of resilience-enhancing measures employed by the project upon its completion in each of the three main coastal lagoons, (Idku, Burullus and Manzala coastal lagoons), covering 60% of coastal area of concern.

actual.comment:
Project Management Unit (PMU) focused on implementing the soft measures in Damiatta and Rosetta to Burullus.
In Damiatta, several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority (DPA), Shore Protection Authority (SPA) and Coastal Research Institute (CoRI). A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port.
For the second pilot site (Rosetta to Burullus) where a dike application is tested as a means to protect the area and the international Coastal Road, The selected site for the pilot is nearly flooded each year at high storms. SPA contracted a contractor (ARC Marine) to construct the dike. A site visit was made with the contractor's representative. Construction will start in July 2015.
The PMU also held eight meetings with the project management and executive committees to discuss the progress of the project activities, present any obstacles and recommend ways forward. These meetings proved to be very useful as many obstacles were overcome and many good recommendations were made.
The PMU has also met HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation three times. The first meeting was as part of MWRI Climate Change Committee meeting and was to present the progress made during the year and get HE feedback on this progress. The second and third meeting were to discuss how to move forward the ICZM study after the cancellation of the EU tender. Based upon these meeting, the PMU with the UNDP prepared a letter to the EU which was signed by the HE the Minister explaining the importance of having an ICZM plan for the north coast of Egypt and asking the EU to re reinstate the previously allocated funds for the ICZM and re-tender the study.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of Shoreline protection agency budget includes coastal stabilization measures designed by the project.

baseline.comment: Target is likely to be achieved in. SPA is now convinced that soft measures would help in protecting the long reaches of the shoreline (10s of Kilometers) that is subjected to erosion. SPA has provided good suggestions for the two pilot sites and keen to implement them and maintain them even beyond the project end. It is anticipated that once the pilot projects are implemented, SPA will keep on monitoring them and provide budget to maintain them at high condition grade

actual.comment: Target is still likely to be achieved in. SPA is co-financing the dike pilot application in Rosetta to Burullus. SPA will also monitor the performance of the three implemented alternatives. The best alternative(s) will be implemented by SPA from its own budget.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Outcome 1: strengthened Regulatory Framework and Institutional Capacity to improve resilience of coastal settlements and development infrastructure

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A comprehensive regulatory and institutional framework for coastal adaptation built around ICZM principles and policies in place

baseline.comment: Existing drafts of ICZM policies but donâ€™t account for sea level rise, and were never implemented; only certain specialized staff has knowledge of concrete adaptation measures. Information management systems reflect risks, but not climate-induced risks to CZ. Existing budgetary allocations are insufficient to meet identified adaptation needs

target.comment: By end of the project national ICZM plan finalized, agency assigned to implement and carry out M&E

actual.comment:
The Project team has continued to provide technical support to MWRI, SPA, the Egyptian-Dutch Advisory Panel Project on Water (APP) and the EU to finalize the ICZM plan ToR and procurement. The tender was announced by the EU in July 2014. The project manager helped in evaluating the received EoIs and the shortlisting process. From October 2014 to December 2015, the project manager evaluated with the EU representatives the received offers from 6 contractors. Regrettably, the requests of the first two shortlisted companies to change key members of the project team with less competent professionals, have made their offers non complaint as per the EU procurement rules and accordingly, the tender was cancelled in December 2014.
Since the ICZM Plan is expected to be the guiding framework for all development and shore protection activities in the North Coast of Egypt at least for the next decade, the PMU suggested that part of the funds from the UNDP-GEF Climate Change Adaptation Project (approx. USD 250k) is used to initiate the scooping phase of the Plan over the next couple of months. This proposal was presented to HE the Minister of Water Resources and Irrigation and the Project Executive Committee members who approved this proposal. In mean time, the PMU and UNDP will continue to help the Ministry to secure the remaining funds to enable developing the ICZM Plan in the shortest possible time frame.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Enhanced data management systems to improve ICZM decision-making in place

target.comment: By end of the project NCZMC re-activated and given necessary authority to implement and monitor ICZM and coastal zone decisions. Its members are engaged, committed with clear responsibilities and capacity to carry out responsibilities

actual.comment:
The recruitment process to select a consultant to "Design a National Coastal Observation System for the North Coast of Egypt" was initiated in the last quarter of 2014. The consultancy ToR was advertised on the UNDP – International website from 14 to 28 October 2014. The project received eight applications but none of them were believed to have the relevant experience. The project accordingly sought assistance from the ClimaSouth project and the UNDP Bangkok Regional office to obtain additional CVs and four additional CVs were received.
The most relevant of those four CVs was from Prof. Nadia Pinardi who then apologized due to her busy schedule. Therefore, only three CVs were evaluated by a committee from SPA,CoRI, PMU and UNDP. The process took longer time than expected in order to ensure that selected consultant can undertake this crucial and important task. At the end the committee selected Dr David Glenn Aubrey to carry out this consultancy. This selection was presented to and approved by the Project Executive Committee. Dr Aubrey was contracted in May 2015 and undertaken a two week visit to Egypt in 9-22 May 2015 to assess the existing monitoring capabilities in Egypt. it is anticipated that David will complete the design by November 2015. Meanwhile, the project will support procurement of the first monitoring equipment to be installed in the system.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: SPA budget lines earmarked specifically for adaptive capacity

target.comment: SPA has mandate, skills and tools to screen current and future investments for climate risk;

actual.comment: Still not initiated. The change in SPA mandate is linked to the work on the new law and the development of a new institutional setup for ICZM as well as the work on the development of ICZM Plan. Meanwhile the introduction of new budget lines will be associated with the completion of the ICZM Plan

target.comment: At least 30 personnel from relevant institutions are trained in climate risk assessment and economic valuation methods;

actual.comment: The target has been achieved but the capacity building activities will continue with the on the job training on the design and implementation of the soft engineering solutions.

target.comment: Within first year of project, information management system and data protocol established

actual.comment: This is now part of the National observation system consultancy. Part of its outputs is to develop an information management system and establish data protocols and data quality control guidelines. this is likely to be ready by the end of 2015.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2. Strategies and measures that facilitate adaptation to climate change impacts, SLR in particular, are implemented on the ground in vulnerable coastal areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Living Shoreline approach adopted to sustain functions and productivity in each of the vulnerable lagoons, in the face of sea level rise, through preserving existing wetlands and lagoon ecosystems and enhancing their functionality.

baseline.comment: To date, shore protection has been dominated by hard protection measures; lagoon functionality and productivity is at risk due to predominantly non-climate factors.

target.comment: Nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and ensure that lagoon borders are at least 2.0 m above lagoons water level

actual.comment:
For the first pilot site In Damiatta (nourishment of eroding beaches), several meetings have been held between the Damiatta Port Authority (DPA), Shore Protection Authority (SPA) and Coastal Research Institute (CoRI). A road map was signed on 21 January 2015 detailing the steps that will be undertaken by each organisation to nourish the eroding breaches near Damiatta with the dredged material from the approach channel of the port. In this road map, the following was agreed:
1- SPA to build sedimentation basins beside the western wall of the port from the project budget.
2- DPA to dump the dredged materiel into the sedimentation basins which is estimated to cost LE 60 million to be paid by DPA
3- SPA to transfer the dredged material from the sedimentation basins to nourish the eroding beaches in Damiatta area to be paid from SPA’s own budget.
4- PMU to explore available options to extract the black sand from the dredged material with relevant organisations in Egypt such as the Nuclear Material Authority (NMA). A monthly meeting is held with all parties to follow up the progress of the implementation of the road map. to date the following progress has been made:
1- SPA selected a contractor to build the sedimentation basins and a contract will be signed in July 2015.
2- DPA selected a contractor to dredge the approach channel and he/she will dump the material in the sedimentation basin.
3- SPA will nourish the eroding breached once 1 and 2 above are on going
4- PMU met with the chairman of NMA and the senior project manager of the black sand project in Egypt. It was agreed that more samples will be taken and analysed from the dredged material to ensure economic feasibility of the extraction of the black sand. A meeting was also held with a DPA representative to coordinate this process.
In addition to the above the PMU has recruited a consultant to assess the economic Feasibility of using the dredged
material from Damietta Port approach channel for sand nourishment. This study was undertaken based on a recommendation from the project steering and executive committees.

baseline.comment: Wastewater discharge

target.comment: Re-vegetation to stabilize seabed sediment (Idku lagoon)

baseline.comment: has changed pH and reduced lagoon productivity;
depletion of fisheries As a result of the human activities and land

target.comment: Beach nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and maintenance of lagoon border at least 2.5m above water level (Burullus lagoon).

actual.comment:
Further to the previous studies undertaken by CoRI, the PMU contracted a team of researchers to carry out and economic feasibility assessment of using dredged material from Damietta port approach channel for sand nourishment. The main objectives of the study were to:
(1) Assess the present and future costs (up to 2050) of the following:
current dredging techniques into the offshore areas, extraction of black sand from dredged material, protection of nearby areas using the dredged material as a source for sand nourishment, hard solutions and other sources.
(2) Evaluate of the economic feasibility of a number of possible shoreline protection alternatives as possible mean for combating erosion at the nearby areas and select the best viable protection measure based on end results of
this evaluation.
(3) Assess how beneficial the nourishment approach could facilitate better sustainable future adaptation to climate change for other recipient areas in the Nile Delta.
The study concluded that the option of beach nourishment is found to be most appropriate for protection areas near Damietta port, whereas a combination of groins and sand nourishment seems to be more relevant for the area east of Ezzbet Elborg.

baseline.comment: reclamation projects, total
area of El Burullus lagoon reduced during last century from 5,600 km3 (1925) to 317.2

target.comment: Beach nourishment, plant/stone/sand fill placement allow for coast stabilization and maintenance of lagoon border at least 2.5m above water level in both the lagoon and canal;

actual.comment:
For the second pilot site (Rosetta to Burullus) where a dike application is tested as a means to protect the area and the international Coastal Road, the following progress has been made:
- A topographic survey was completed for the area to find suitable locations for the pilot application.
- SPA and CoRI staff selected three suitable locations based upon the survey
- A site visit was undertaken by SPA, CoRI and PMU to check the conditions at each of the selected locations.
- A final selection was made based on the site visit. The selected site is nearly flooded each year at high storms.
- SPA and CoRI staff designed 3 dike alternatives which will be constructed at the selected location to find out the best option (s).
- SPA tendered the job and undertaken technical and financial evaluation of the received offers.
- SPA contracted a contractor (ARC Marine) to construct the dike.
- A site visit was made with the contractor's representative.
- Construction will start in July 2015.

baseline.comment: km3 (1984) and now 197.8 km3 (2001); urban sewage and agriculture drainage has led to eutrophication.

The Manzala lagoon is the largest and most productive Lake in terms of its fisheries, estimated annual fish landings is roughly 60,000 tons. Since 1965, it has been receiving increasing amounts of agricultural runoff, industrial waste discharge, and sewage effluent that have led to eutrophication, decreased biodiversity, and reduced habitat for marine and avian species.

target.comment: Erosion rate held constant and begins to decline to by .5 m/yr (Manzala lagoon);
By end of the project methods and practice of climate riks assessment, socio-economic valuation (CBA) of adaptation options are established as part of the ICZM framework

baseline.comment: See outcome 2 (above)

target.comment: See outcome 2 (above)

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3. Knowledge management: M&A framework and knowledge management system in place Output 3.1: Guidance documents for GEF and MWRI on climate change adaptation programming in the coastal zones provided

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Knowledge and capacity for upscale and replication is in place

baseline.comment: No cases of best practices recorded

target.comment: At the time of project completion, at least 3 examples of best practice generated through the project will be accessible through the ALM.

actual.comment: The PMU has reassessed the training needs of the project partners. This was done in consultation with them. A number of training programs have been proposed to them and to the project executive committee based on this assessment. The proposal has been approved by the project executive committee and the project is now in the process of holding those programs.

baseline.comment: Knowledge of adaptation measures in the context of coastal protection is very limited.

target.comment: Stakeholders knowledge on adaptation measures integration with coastal protection imporved

actual.comment: No activities done in this respect this year but will resume after initiation of the work on the ICZM plan (i.e. the scoping study)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: LSA reflected in government entitiesâ€™ coastal management plans relevant to their unique mandate

target.comment: Within 6 months of the start of implementation, a publicly accessible web-site will be created to share lessons and findings based on implementation.

actual.comment: The project continues to update and maintain the website

baseline.comment: There is no knowledge or awareness of the living shoreline approach (LSA) as an effective strategy for coastal adaptation

target.comment: At the time of project completion, at least 3 examples of lessons learned a year have been compiled and disseminated
a program to build awareness within Egyptian institutions regarding living shoreline approach; climate-proofed ICZM framework includes LSA as a national adaptation strategy

actual.comment: No activities done in this respect this year but will resume after initiation of work on the ICZM plan (i.e. the scoping study)

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: A Social Insurance system is integrated with functioning call centers, a website for the social insurance authority. An effective project management is established. Reports and studies are conducted about Policy and technical support provided for the Minister of finance. The PPP approach to government investment projects is monitored.

baseline.comment: MOF is an economic actor in Egypt’s development, but it has played so far a traditional role as a controller of income and expenditures only. The project aims at supportinging MoF as an economic actor in Egypt’s development. MOF’s traditional role of being the government’s financial arm and controller of income and expenditure was extended to being the source of macro-fiscal policy advice to the government during the last cooperation phase with UNDP furthermore, by focusing on the restructuring and automation of the Authority for Social Insurance. The MOF is further increasing its social and economic impact, in line with the role of financial ministries in developed countries.

target.comment: • A new comprehensive framework for public financial management (PFM) reform developed including Government Financial Management Information System (GFMIS) and a cohesive action plan • Awareness raised on the concept of the Economic Justice Unit (EJU). The unit is being established with the aim of supporting the modernization of the informal sector, the establishment of a targeting system for the poor and the implementation of economic programs aiming to harmonize financial policies with social considerations. • A high level cross-functional technical committee representing government, civil society and business sector established to support the integration of the informal sector

actual.comment: • There was a close cooperation with Central Bank of Egypt to reach a comprehensive view towards the approach of automating the budget execution/ Analysis Report, identifying program risks with the moderation scheme, have been finalized and submitted to management with recommendations. • The Economic Justice Unit (EJU):  Conducted several meetings with delegation from the World Bank to discuss short to medium term assistance needs of the Ministry of Finance.  The unit met with representatives from various investment banks, international development agencies, banks, embassies, and International Financial Institutions to discuss possible cooperation. • High level cross-functional technical committee was established.

target.comment: • Implement reform activities in Internal Audit and automate Full payroll • Provide technical assistance to Macro-fiscal policy unit • Support international & regional events and legal advice • Build the Capacity of Public Private Partnership (PPP) unit

actual.comment: • The first “Strategic Planning Forum” was organized during 2015 to develop MOF’s vision, strategic goals in cooperation. A second forum targeting the development of tactical targets and the high level strategic plan for the ministry is planned for early 2016. • Internal Audit roadmap and IT unit’s mandate are being developed. • Payroll automation Studies have been conducted and are being reviewed. • Monthly memos covering main macroeconomic and fiscal updates, pension law, and global economic development were prepared. • Several meetings and events with representatives from various investment banks, international development agencies, banks, embassies and International Financial Institutions were organized. • Trainings and workshops for 30 PPP unit employees were conducted. • PPP projects were promoted in several regional and international conferences and summits. • The tendering process of the new 8 PPP projects that were announced in the Egypt Economic Development Conference (EEDC) held in Sharm el sheikh has beeb started by PPP unit.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To improve the energy efficiency of end-use equipment, namely building appliances and lighting systems manufactured, marketed and used in Egypt

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The level of compliance of the targeted appliances with the adopted minimum energy performance standards (a priori the MEPS to be adopted in Egypt are expected to be in line with those adopted in EU.)

baseline.comment: From 10% to 50% higher energy consumption (depending on the appliance) when comparing to the planned MEPS (for further details see Annex 7-4).

target.comment: Over 80% of the appliances sold in the Egyptian market are in compliance with the requirements of those MEPS and labeling schemes that are expected to be in force by the end of the project (for further details see Annex 7-5).

actual.comment:
The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy has launched a National initiative for disseminating LED lamps to the residential sector. The Ministry contracted a supplier to provide 13 million LED lamps with different wattage (4,6,9 watt) to be sold on installments added to electricity bills. The project provided the Ministry with the technical specifications and testing procedures for tendering purposes.
To date, more than 1.8 Million lamps have been sold via Electricity Distribution Companies, thus achieving an estimated saving of 40 Million KWh for the 3 month period from the starting selling date up to 30/06/2015.
Different government entities are working on reducing electricity consumption as per the Cabinet instructions for all government buildings to reduce electricity consumption by 20%.
The Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy signed a protocol of cooperation with the Ministry of Local Development and the Arab Organization for Industrialization for LE 2.3 billion to increase efficiency of street lighting systems to replace the 400 watt and 250 sodium lamps by high efficient 150 and 100 watt sodium lamps respectively. The total number of lamps has been estimated at 4 million lamps and the project duration is expected to be around 3 years. The first stage is for replacing 0.5 million lamps, up till now 150000, 400 watt lamps have been replaced by 150 watt. In the mean time, the previous program initiated by the Ministry of Electricity and Energy for increasing street lighting efficiency is still ongoing in some governorates but through their own resources with the assistance of the electricity distribution companies, this includes (CFLs 85-125 watt, replacing 100 and150 watt sodium lamps with electronic ballast). Meanwhile, The New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) announced issuing a contract for LE 70 million to change all street lighting systems in the new cities to LED systems
Ministry of Tourism has announced an innovative lending program offering loans to hotels for replacing lighting systems and installing solar water heaters that will be settled based on the occupancy rate in the hotel
Ministry of Industry has released a Ministerial decree to activate MEPS for fans and dishwashers.
Egyptian Organization for Standardization (EOS) activated, in cooperation with other key relevant authorities, the new national S& L programme enforcement mechanism to confirm the compliance of the issued labels with the developed MEPS. These labels are released based on the testing results performed at NREA’s labs established in the first phase of the project.
Based on the results of the Energy Efficiency tests (NREA) and the issued labels from (EOS) ,Mmost of the released labels are rated either A or B except for the air conditioners which are rated C,D,E but still an improvement when compared to previous results showing a lower rate of compliance where some of the tested units were not complying with the MEPS.
Meanwhile the level of efficiency of these appliances have improved comparing to the last year levels
The awareness campaign that has been launched last year for increasing public awareness of energy efficiency through the young students will continue this year but on a larger scale to cover 10 of the Egyptian governorates through the cooperation with the NGOs working with the Small Grants Program of GEF and the Consumer Agency Protection.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

baseline.comment: See the baseline scenario presented in Annex 7-4.

target.comment: Direct incremental reduction of GHG emissions by 0.95 million tons of CO2eq by the end of the project and estimated cumulative indirect GHG emission reduction of at least 53 million tons of CO2eq by 2025 on the basis of a conservative policy scenario and a GEF causality factor of 60%.

actual.comment:
The achieved energy savings from this reporting period have been estimated at 477,109 MWh equating to 0.257 MTons CO2 based on a grid emission factor of 0.54 tons of CO2/ MWh.
These savings are calculated for a three months period for the LED lighting program and the street lighting program which is the period starting from the selling date and date of starting of street lighting program up to end of June, while for the impact resulting from raising the set point of air conditioners from 16 degree centigrade to 21 degree centigrade the calculated savings are calculated for a 4 month period, the savings of the implemented efficient lighting pilot projects have been calculated based on the ending date of each project..
.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Accelerated growth of the EE lighting market in Egypt, in line with the Global UNEP-UNDP EE Lighting initiative.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Total volume or the market share of the CFLs and other EE lighting appliances in Egypt

baseline.comment:
CFLs: No new MEPS adopted + annual sale of 25 million CFLs reached by 2015 as a result of a continuing natural growth.
LFLs and HIDs: No new EE requirements formally adopted and reflected in public procurement processes.

target.comment:
CFLs: Annual sale of 35 million CFLs reached by 2015 resulting from projectâ€™s market promotion activities + new MEPS adopted for completely phasing out incandescent light bulbs as per the schedule elaborated in Annex 7-5.
LFLs and HIDs (street Lighting): The second set of EU consistent EE requirements have entered into force , they are reflected in the technical specifications for public procurement and less than 10% of the random samples tested show non-compliance.

actual.comment:
The project has implemented more than 15 energy efficiency lighting pilot projects supported by technical assistance(audit, techno economic feasibility study, specifications, list of qualified suppliers published also on the web site, preparation of tender documents) in addition to financial contribution varying between 50% of the total cost for public buildings and 25% for private sector buildings that was shared equally with funds from the UNDP Regional Arab Climate Resilience Initiative (ACRI). Projects were implemented in different types of buildings including governmental buildings, administration building, bank, hotels, library, street lighting of residential compounds, retail shop, etc. In addition, the project is providing technical assistance with no financial contribution to a number of other entities including large chain of supermarkets in Egypt and some other private sector facilities
Press releases for the implemented projects are issued in different newspapers announcing the projects results to increase general awareness. Case studies and promotional brochures are under preparation to document the savings that varied between 25-40% of the total electricity bill and a payback period of between six months and one year in most buildings. Brochures will be distributed in awareness seminars directed to targeted groups to advocate for replication at the National level
Some of projects beneficiaries have decided to replicate the projects in their facilities mainly the CIB bank, Marriott hotels, the New Urban Communities Authority of the Ministry of Housing.
The project organized three training courses on “Auditing and Energy Efficiency Lighting in buildings” attended by 73 engineers from various Ministries. The project in cooperation with the Housing and Building Research Center has organized 4 training courses on the Energy Efficiency street lighting code. The courses were attended by 138 trainees from all relevant authorities.
A special training course for design and implementation of lighting projects in hotels was jointly funded by EU MED ENEC Project in cooperation with the Ministry of Tourism and conducted by an international consultant. The project sponsored a visit for the President of the Chinese National Lighting Testing Center (NLTC) to lecture in the training workshop.
The project supported EOS to develop specifications for different types of LED lighting lamps.
The National Consulting firm contracted to evaluate the street lighting situation in Egypt has assessed the situation and evaluated achievements and draw backs of the energy efficiency implemented street lighting project. Outputs and recommendations of the study will be shared with senior officials of the Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy.
A simplified version of the Energy efficiency street lighting code has been prepared by the consultant and will be handed to local authorities and municipalities engineers.
A database model has also been developed to enable model users testing different options for street lighting energy efficiency projects, needed investments and expected savings.
Upon formal request from the New Urban Communities Authority, the project has recruited a specialized international consultant to provide technical assistance for the implementation of a pilot project for PV/LED street lighting project in a six Km desert road. Conceptual design as well as the bidding documents have been prepared. On job- training has also been provided by the consultant.
Within the memorandum of understanding signed with the Energy Efficiency Unit (EEU) of the Cabinet of Ministers, more than 35 energy audits were conducted by the project in different government buildings where transformation to efficient lighting was co- funded by the EEU

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: A comprehensive S&L scheme for building appliances developed and effectively implemented, matching international and regional best policy and technology practices, and with energy efficiency requirements set at a level where cost effectiveness is proven.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The status and content of the legal and regulatory acts and the agreed implementation arrangements dealing with appliance minimum energy performance standards (MEPS), labeling schemes and their enforcement.

baseline.comment: Minimum energy performance standards and/or labeling schemes developed and adopted for 5 appliances (CFLs, refrigerators/freezers, washing machines, air-conditioners and electric water heaters), but not adequately enforced and monitored yet.

target.comment:
Strengthened implementation, enforcement and market monitoring of the S&L schemes adopted for the first five appliances to cover both import and local production as demonstrated by verified annual statistics on the sale of the different appliances sold as per the different energy classes.
Expanded S&L, implementation, enforcement and market monitoring schemes formally adopted for new appliances consisting of: TVs and their accessories, information and communication appliances (ICT), stand-by power, external power supply (EPS), electric fans and electric motors as per the schedule presented in Annex 7-5.

actual.comment:
The project supports Egyptian Organization for Standardization in developing MEPS for fans and dish washers and the Ministerial decree for enforcement has been issued as well as the informative labels for the two appliances.
Contract was signed with a supplier to establish a testing laboratory for fans in Egyptian Organization for Standards (EOS) and tendering process for establishing testing labs for dishwaters and pumps is still ongoing
The project is supporting EOS in developing the MEPS for household appliances where the final draft has been prepared for TVs and water pumps and in process for the ovens, compressors and inverter air conditioners.
A national consulting firm was contracted to conduct a survey and assessment of household appliances energy consumption patterns. First draft of the report is submitted including preliminary analysis of survey data of 5000 samples in 5 governorates Cairo, Alexandria, Giza, Ismalyia and Menya,. The report analyzed the degree of saturation for the different appliances, but some data were not easily obtained mainly the power consumption and the duration of use per month. These issues will be dealt with in the final report which will also include detailed analysis of the consumption patterns.
The EE unit at EOS initiated the new S&L monitoring mechanism that has been developed for issuing the labels that will have a serial number and a barcode stored in a data base at EOS to allow authorized inspecting authorities to verify the information on the label. The software has been developed and the project has supplied EOS and Consumer Protection Agency with four hand held units to inspect the barcodes in the market. Over the last 6 month period, EOS issued 40 labels for the refrigerators 24 rated A and 16 rated B. 31 labels for deep freezers 11 (A) and 13(B) Electric water heaters 21 labels 19(A)1(B) and 1(E). 2 washing machines rated (A).6 air conditioner window type rated (E). 89 split units 10 rated (C) 11 rated (D)and 68 rated (E).16 CFLs 14 rated (A) and 2 rated (B).
Some problems were met when using the software, the project will provide a new version of the software.
The project completed a six months public awareness campaign launched last year through the young volunteers and will initiated again this year. Moreover the project has signed a memorandum of understanding with the GEF Small Grant Program to extend the awareness activities in 10 governorates with the assistance of the NGOs working with the GEF SGP and in coordination with the Consumer Protection Agency.
The project signed an MOU with Consumer Protection Agency to jointly implement an awareness campaign on the S&L programme and ensure more involvement of the civil society in monitoring the energy labels for home appliances and verifying the information on the EE labels

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: The share of non-compliant products.

baseline.comment: (not given)

target.comment: Fewer than 10% of all the random samples tested at the end of the project show non-compliance.

actual.comment:
Based on the test results from NREA testing laboratories and issued labels from EOS, the rate of compliance with the minimum energy performance standards MEPS has increased: 97% for refrigerators ,100% for the electric water heaters, 100% for automatic washing machines,86% for split air conditioners.
Meanwhile the level of efficiency for this reporting period has improved when compared to last year figures
For the refrigerators: 55% are rated A( the highest energy efficiency rating) up from 43% last year.
For washing machines 97% are rated A up from 94% last year. For electric water heaters 90% are rated A up from 71% last year.
As for the air conditioners, although the level of compliance has increased but still the efficiency is low..

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sustained project results

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The level of information available for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project.

baseline.comment: Insufficient information for adaptive management and for measuring the impact of the project.

target.comment: Annually updated information on the sale of each targeted appliance as per its energy performance class and the level of compliance with the adopted standards and regulations available.

actual.comment:
The results of the conducted survey on the impact of the awareness programs have been used as a baseline when compared to the outputs of the campaigns organized by the project through the young students, this revealed that the knowledge on energy efficiency measures has improved and the satisfaction of the customers on the way of getting the information through direct contacts rather than media programs.
The market monitoring mechanism has provided the information on the entities that possess the scattered data relating to the annual market size of home appliances and lamps,accordingly ,the project contacted the identified entities to collect market size data of lighting and home appliances but the response was not very positive and still information was not sufficient to establish the data base, nor to evaluate the savings from improving the level of efficiency based on the market size and not on tested samples at the energy efficiency testing laboratories which is giving just an indication but not a level of achieved savings.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability.

baseline.comment: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results.

target.comment: Sustained institutional and financial mechanisms in place to promote the market for EE appliances and related market monitoring.

actual.comment:
The project sustainability will be achieved through the different Energy Efficiency departments that have been established in the Ministry with the support of the World Bank, in the Egyptian Electricity Holding Company and the units that have been created at the level of the 9 electricity distribution companies.
The project activities will be sustained through one of the items included in the Electricity law on Energy Efficiency and which has already been ratified.
The project will be sustained through the different MEPS that have developed for the home appliances and the testing laboratories established at the New and Renewable Energy Authority and the Egyptian Organization for Standards.
Sustainability will be achieved through the effective activation of the developed Market Monitoring System that has been developed after resolving the problems encountered and with cooperation with the different relevant authorities responsible of monitoring the Standards and Labeling Program.
Sustainability will also be achieved through the Loan Guarantee Mechanism that will be sustained even after the project termination, as the agreement is signed between the Loan Guarantee Company and the Egyptian Electricity Holding Company. The total issued guarantees have reached 30 Million L.E for 84 projects, the total expired guarantees 23 Million L.E for 51 projects and the total outstanding guarantees 6,690 Million L.E for 33 projects, and is trying to leverage the budget of the loan guarantee program to enable more projects implementation.
